I've only played 5 hours so far so here's my early impressions: It's already better than F1 2015 in every way. I put over 50 hours into F1 2015.  First off, the game was is more optismised than than last year's title. On my 970, I'm getting over 100 fps on high settings in both dry and wet conditions. Wet conditions on the previous game would always have severe drops to 30-40 when driving near a few other cars. The last game also had micro stutters occasionly. I have yet to get any in this game.  The actual driving is largely the same. I've noticed the rear tyres don't spin up as much which I always thought was a bit extreme in F1 2015. It's still more arcadey than sim but honestly I'm fine with that. The addition of steam workshop support for car setups is a nice feature.  It's got a proper career mode! And the best in the series to date! I love the addition of the track acclimatisation, tyre management and qualifying simulation programs in the practice sessions. It's a great way of prepping for the race and improving your car during the season by earning R&D points. I started my career in Manor with the aim of bringing the team closer to the front of the grid.  I've seen a few bugs, such as a UI graphic that stayed on screen for an entire race and a floating ghost driver during a single-shot qualifying session. No crashes thus far. The multiplayer isn't broken at launch like the last game.  I just want to play more!

I'm an occasionnal racing game player and so far I love F1 2016. I was hesitant to pick this one up because of all the bad reviews and bugs from the last year version.   No crash or bugs. I had no problems running this game with a gtx 980ti with 60fps or more all the time on Acer predator X34 (21:9 ratio supported). There seems to be performance issue with the player hub in carreer mode where the fps drop really low but that wont keep you from enjoying the game. My only deception is that the game don't support multi gpu SLI.  My thrustmaster t500rs wheel work really well and the forcefeed back is amazing. No configuration needed. Everything just work as it should.  Graphics are good espescially in rain condition. I think Project cars look better than this.  Gameplay is great. It's a bit more arcade than Project cars but I like this way. The cars feel and handle very good. You wont have you car drifting and going out of control if you push the gas pedal too hard like Pcars. It's alot less punishing when you make a mistake.  I mostly played the carreer mode. It's very addicve as you'll want to make your pilot progress by completing team objectives, face to face challenge and gain experience points that you can spend to upgrade your car by achieving race objective. Unlike the empty and uninteresting Pcars carreer mode this one is great.  The ai seems ok. They wont bump into you unless you make something really unsual. I'm playing at medium difficulty and I'm having alot of fun.  The voice control for strategy, pit options and info on the race is a nice feature. I like it. It's easier to stay focus on the race than trying to manually navigate the menu.  I compared alot to Pcars because this was my favorite racing sim with a wheel. I never played any F1 20xx before.  Overall it's a must buy if you like F1 racing game.

My final rating for the game is 8.5/10. I would give it 10/10 for the amout of fun I had with it but there are still few things that need improvement that will hopefully be fixed through patches.

I'm pretty impressed with it. I generally prefer racing games that fall on the more realistic simulation side of things like Assetto Corsa and Project Cars. (More Assetto Corsa these days). I was a bit worried about how F1 2016 would feel/handle and FFB. I just spent about 40 laps at Melbourne in time trial mode getting a feel for things and once i got FFB and controls setup it feels quite good to me. I was afraid Assetto may have spoiled me with the SF15/F138 they recently released but i think the F1 cars in this game are very good and on par with the Assetto models. I only tried expert mode with all assists off and it seems quite 'realistic' (Well as realistic as i'll ever know.. given i'll never touch one of these cars IRL)  I had some intermittent issues with steering initially... 1st: i had to turn my wheel all the way to get the car to turn at all.. the ratio seemed way off and too slow. found the steering saturation option and bumped it to 75 which seemed to fix that. 2nd: occasionally i'd have an issue where i had zero FFB and the saturation setting above wasnt working.. It seemed to go away after crashing into something. (Using a Fanatec CSW V2) Time will tell if this persists.  I'm not a huge F1 fan but watch with a passive interest. This is my first game from the official F1 series but overall i think this game is very solid. Looking forward to the career options. I dunno if you'd call it a sim or arcade or simcade, but at this point I think the physics are very good and will it will provide a lot of fun and replay-ability.  Graphics look very good and i'm glad to have some unique tracks that i dont have access to from any other games like COTA and Singapore.

Although the past couple of years left a bitter taste, I decided to take a leap of faith and get the F1 2016 game on pre-purchase offer and it was a good decision  I've only played 5 hours of the game and the impressions are so much better than 2014/2015 versions.  Here are the things I most enjoyed during this short amount of time:  The career mode is what makes it all fun, choose a low-end team and race your way to the top;  Personalize your driver by choosing name, looks, nationality and obviously an Ayrton Senna like helmet;  You can develop the car (R&D) along the practice seasons by completing some goals that will also help you to drive better;  Control your entire career through your laptop;  Beating your teammate is always rewarding;  Get the best out of your car at the start of the race by feeding the throttle and releasing the clutch at the exact moment;  Watch the pre-race and post-race actions.   There are some downsides also:   The AI keeps hammering your rear wing under braking, so annoying;  There is still lots of wheel spin making it too arcade;  After the rain, the track starts to dry slowly and naturally but then hits a turning point where it gets completely dry out of the blue and it is hard to define which strategy to follow.  The FFB could be improved, the loose center is still there when using a G27 for example.   Overall, it is a good game and in one weekend, I've already played it much more than the previous two versions.

F1 99-02 was my favourite F1 game because it was the first one I got (and also for a long time), but now I truly consider F1 2016 my best F1 game. With the roots of the new engine monde behind F1 2015, Codemasters could have just re-implemented the career mode from F1 2014 and make it F1 2015 2. Instead they decided to overhaul the whole Career mode, add a new Time system to the weather system, give more depth with the character creation, improving some aspects of F1 2015...etc  The R&D system, which is the biggest change of the game, seems to be the one who anger a lot of the community, but it really rely on how you play : you don't have that much time and you want to quickly win ? Rush the R&D and make Haas Great Again. You have tons of time and you want to feel a more realistic competition ? Go slow on the R&D and beat the AI on tracks with skill.  There are still some flows like the AI stacking themselves when some crash happened, or coming to pitstop for dry tyres just before the rain. But overall the game really made a huge step forward and gives a lot of hope from Codemasters, as lot of ideas in the game were given by players who answered a survey or by the forums (like the new Master Difficulty in one of the patches). Without comparing to others games of the series, I would rate it 8/10.

10/10.  Well, what can I say. After many years of feeling 'bored' with F1 games, they finaly went and hit the nail on the head with this one. Everything we asked for; formation lap, safety car, career mode, helmet customization has all been added. But not only have they been added, they've been done correctly and not just 'thrown' in.   Here's my opinion on different parts of the game.  Career Mode: What can I say. I was very excited and eager to start. I was first faced with Character customization, which was simple and yet efficient. Then it was the team selection, Which I'm glad you can choose any team as it makes it more 'personal' rather than being forced your Path.  R&D: As we know it, Research & Development was kind of the weakness in the past years. But this time, it brings a whole new meaning, not only do you improve. Other teams improve and even some don't. But... I honestly think R&D is too easy & too early. In my 1st season with Haas & into the 14th race. Toro Rosso was already 3rd Fastest, Which seemed a little unrealistic. But other than that, it's perfect.  Safety & Virtual Safety Car: Finaly. it's back! F1 2015 felt rushed without the safety car, although the Graphics was massively improved from 2014 and some will even argue they're still the best to this day for CM. With it completely been re-done, it feels much better. Although at times, it doesn't come out when it should and it comes out when it shouldn't. In my 2 seasons I've only had 1 VSC, so other than it being rare. I can't really give feedback other than it worked great when it did happen.  But yeah that's it. The Game is great again. Thanks.

So, i've been away from PC driving sims for some time. Largely because i got rid of my wheel, and also because every sim I've tried in recent history has had inferior driving 'feel' to the gran turismo series on the playstation when played with a controller.  F1 2016 feels 'right' to drive. I'm using a 360 controller and feel that i can do with the car what i want, and handling feels like it should, given that i have never driven F1 before, the physics seem feasible.  The AI is particularly good, and a vast improvement on anything i've played before. Out brake a rival into a corner for example, and they will give room and try to cut back, rather than just plow into you or back way off like in other games. There's actually some semblance of intelligence there, rather than just sitting on line.  Recommended.

A much improved effort from Codemasters, and perhaps the best Formula 1 game I have played in years. Manual stars and manual pit stops add to a more immersive experience, along with the safety car and the virtual safety car. Overall, the game just feels like more of a simulation than it has in previous iterations.  I am quite enjoying career mode, along with the implementation of communicating to the race engineer during a race. Although this can be distracting at times, this can be turn off by telling your race engineer to shut up.  There is some slight stuttering of frames, as well as sound, but I would hope this is addressed in time.  A few hours in, I do not regret the purchase and I can safely say Codemasters have listened to the community. You really feel like you're in the moment.

The driving is excellent, career mode is awesome, and they even added R&D tasks to practice sessions. You can drive all 3 practice sessions with an objective besides just practicing, which earns you research points to upgrade your car- love it!  Sadly Codemasters contune to hate PC gamers with no mouse support for the menu. The game is supurb but the menus are a pain to navigate with the keyboard or your wheel. They do work well with a controller as that was what it was designed for.

Solid development of F1 2015, although I don't really care for the RPG fluff - which adds to the size of the game - I'd just as well skip contract lawyer Emma Jenkins...  The post processing won't be to everybody's liking, but that's not unusual territory for Codies. Plenty of their games improve after changing the default post processing and other graphical settings.  Minor issues - geforce experience appears to crash the game (no big deal) - turbo sounds like an irritating hiss (feature or bug?) - time trial has delays as it updates rival data (like 2015) - anti-alias and post processing not perfect  Positives - runs like a beast on a GTX 1080 at 1920x1080 with maximum settings - dfgt setup basically same as 2015 - thank god(!) - looks good - close racing - tweak the level of challenge to your own liking  System I7 4790k w. 16gb GTX 1080 Windows 10 64bit Logitech DFGT
